questions.text: What is the key principle of effective delegation?
options: Dumping all your work on others
Transfer both responsibility and authority - empower others to own outcomes, not just tasks
questions.explanation: Effective delegation gives both the task AND the authority to complete it. Don't just delegate tasks ('do this'); delegate outcomes ('achieve this result however you see fit'). Provide: (1) Clear desired outcome, (2) Context/constraints, (3) Authority to make decisions, (4) Resources needed, (5) Check-in schedule. Then step back. Micromanaging isn't delegation.

questions.text: What is the '$10/hour vs $1000/hour' activity framework?
options: Identifying which tasks create low value vs high value - delegate low-value work to focus on high-leverage activities
questions.explanation: Ask: 'Is this a $10/hour activity (admin, scheduling, data entry) or $1000/hour activity (strategy, relationship building, high-level decisions)?' Successful people relentlessly focus on high-value activities and delegate/automate the rest. Track your time for a week. Any $10/hour work you're doing? Delegate it. Your time is your scarcest resource.

questions.text: What is a Virtual Assistant (VA) and when should you hire one?
options: A remote professional who handles administrative tasks - hire when your time is worth more than their cost
questions.explanation: A VA handles: email management, scheduling, research, data entry, social media, customer service, bookkeeping. Cost: $5-50/hour depending on skills/location. Hire when: (1) You're doing work worth less than your hourly rate, (2) Tasks are repeatable/trainable, (3) You're working IN your business, not ON it. Start 5-10 hours/week with clear SOPs.
